name: accessibilityFeatures
description: Use the chrome.accessibilityFeatures API to manage Chrome's accessibility features. This API relies on the ChromeSetting prototype of the type API for getting and setting individual accessibility features. In order to get feature states the extension must request accessibilityFeatures.read permission. For modifying feature state, the extension needs accessibilityFeatures.modify permission. Note that accessibilityFeatures.modify does not imply accessibilityFeatures.read permission.

name: alarms
description: Use the chrome.alarms API to schedule code to run periodically or at a specified time in the future.

item_data_arr.name: create
item_data_arr.description:
Creates an alarm. Near the time(s) specified by alarmInfo, the onAlarm event is fired. If there is another alarm with the same name (or no name if none is specified), it will be cancelled and replaced by this alarm.

In order to reduce the load on the user's machine, Chrome limits alarms to at most once every 1 minute but may delay them an arbitrary amount more. That is, setting delayInMinutes or periodInMinutes to less than 1 will not be honored and will cause a warning. when can be set to less than 1 minute after "now" without warning but won't actually cause the alarm to fire for at least 1 minute.

To help you debug your app or extension, when you've loaded it unpacked, there's no limit to how often the alarm can fire.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          name
item_data_arr.description: Optional name to identify this alarm. Defaults to the empty string.

item_data_arr.name: alarmInfo
item_data_arr.description: Describes when the alarm should fire. The initial time must be specified by either when or delayInMinutes (but not both). If periodInMinutes is set, the alarm will repeat every periodInMinutes minutes after the initial event. If neither when or delayInMinutes is set for a repeating alarm, periodInMinutes is used as the default for delayInMinutes.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                when
item_data_arr.description: Time at which the alarm should fire, in milliseconds past the epoch (e.g. Date.now() + n).

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                delayInMinutes
item_data_arr.description: Length of time in minutes after which the onAlarm event should fire.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                periodInMinutes
item_data_arr.description: If set, the onAlarm event should fire every periodInMinutes minutes after the initial event specified by when or delayInMinutes. If not set, the alarm will only fire once.

item_data_arr.name: get
item_data_arr.description: Retrieves details about the specified alarm.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          name
item_data_arr.description: The name of the alarm to get. Defaults to the empty string.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function( Alarm alarm) {...};

item_data_arr.name: getAll
item_data_arr.description: Gets an array of all the alarms.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(array of Alarm alarms) {...};

item_data_arr.name: clear
item_data_arr.description: Clears the alarm with the given name.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          name
item_data_arr.description: The name of the alarm to clear. Defaults to the empty string.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function(boolean wasCleared) {...};

item_data_arr.name: clearAll
item_data_arr.description: Clears all alarms.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function(boolean wasCleared) {...};

name: browserAction
description: Use browser actions to put icons in the main Google Chrome toolbar, to the right of the address bar. In addition to its icon, a browser action can have a tooltip, a badge, and a popup.

item_data_arr.name: setTitle
item_data_arr.description: Sets the title of the browser action. This title appears in the tooltip.

item_data_arr.name: title
item_data_arr.description: The string the browser action should display when moused over.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                tabId
item_data_arr.description: Limits the change to when a particular tab is selected. Automatically resets when the tab is closed.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: getTitle
item_data_arr.description: Gets the title of the browser action.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                tabId
item_data_arr.description: The tab to get the title from. If no tab is specified, the default title is returned.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(string result) {...};

item_data_arr.name: setIcon
item_data_arr.description: Sets the icon for the browser action. The icon can be specified as the path to an image file, as the pixel data from a canvas element, or as a dictionary of one of those. Either the path or the imageData property must be specified.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                imageData
item_data_arr.description: Either an ImageData object or a dictionary {size -> ImageData} representing an icon to be set. If the icon is specified as a dictionary, the image used is chosen depending on the screen's pixel density. If the number of image pixels that fit into one screen space unit equals scale, then an image with size scale * n is selected, where n is the size of the icon in the UI. At least one image must be specified. Note that 'details.imageData = foo' is equivalent to 'details.imageData = {'16': foo}'

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                path
item_data_arr.description: Either a relative image path or a dictionary {size -> relative image path} pointing to an icon to be set. If the icon is specified as a dictionary, the image used is chosen depending on the screen's pixel density. If the number of image pixels that fit into one screen space unit equals scale, then an image with size scale * n is selected, where n is the size of the icon in the UI. At least one image must be specified. Note that 'details.path = foo' is equivalent to 'details.path = {'16': foo}'

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                tabId
item_data_arr.description: Limits the change to when a particular tab is selected. Automatically resets when the tab is closed.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: setPopup
item_data_arr.description: Sets the HTML document to be opened as a popup when the user clicks the browser action icon.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                tabId
item_data_arr.description: Limits the change to when a particular tab is selected. Automatically resets when the tab is closed.

item_data_arr.name: popup
item_data_arr.description: The HTML file to show in a popup. If set to the empty string (''), no popup is shown.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.description: Gets the HTML document that is set as the popup for this browser action.

(optional)
                                tabId
item_data_arr.description: The tab to get the popup from. If no tab is specified, the non-tab-specific popup is returned.

item_data_arr.description:

name: browsingData
description: Use the chrome.browsingData API to remove browsing data from a user's local profile.

item_data_arr.description: Reports which types of data are currently selected in the 'Clear browsing data' settings UI. Note: some of the data types included in this API are not available in the settings UI, and some UI settings control more than one data type listed here.

name: certificateProvider
description: Use this API to expose certificates to the platform which can use these certificates for TLS authentications.

item_data_arr.name: requestPin
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 57.

Requests the PIN from the user. Only one ongoing request at a time is allowed. The requests issued while another flow is ongoing are rejected. It's the extension's responsibility to try again later if another flow is in progress.

item_data_arr.name: details
item_data_arr.description: Contains the details about the requested dialog.

item_data_arr.name: signRequestId
item_data_arr.description: The ID given by Chrome in SignRequest.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                requestType
item_data_arr.description: The type of code requested. Default is PIN.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                errorType
item_data_arr.description: The error template displayed to the user. This should be set if the previous request failed, to notify the user of the failure reason.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                attemptsLeft
item_data_arr.description: The number of attempts left. This is provided so that any UI can present this information to the user. Chrome is not expected to enforce this, instead stopPinRequest should be called by the extension with errorType = MAX_ATTEMPTS_EXCEEDED when the number of pin requests is exceeded.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
Is called when the dialog is resolved with the user input, or when the dialog request finishes unsuccessfully (e.g. the dialog was canceled by the user or was not allowed to be shown).

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(object details) {...};

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                        userInput
item_data_arr.description: The code provided by the user. Empty if user closed the dialog or some other error occurred.

item_data_arr.name: stopPinRequest
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 57.

Stops the pin request started by the requestPin function.

item_data_arr.name: details
item_data_arr.description: Contains the details about the reason for stopping the request flow.

item_data_arr.name: signRequestId
item_data_arr.description: The ID given by Chrome in SignRequest.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                errorType
item_data_arr.description: The error template. If present it is displayed to user. Intended to contain the reason for stopping the flow if it was caused by an error, e.g. MAX_ATTEMPTS_EXCEEDED.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
To be used by Chrome to send to the extension the status from their request to close PIN dialog for user.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

name: contentSettings
description: Use the chrome.contentSettings API to change settings that control whether websites can use features such as cookies, JavaScript, and plugins. More generally speaking, content settings allow you to customize Chrome's behavior on a per-site basis instead of globally.

name: contextMenus
description: Use the chrome.contextMenus API to add items to Google Chrome's context menu. You can choose what types of objects your context menu additions apply to, such as images, hyperlinks, and pages.

item_data_arr.name: create
item_data_arr.description: Creates a new context menu item. If an error occurs during creation, it may not be detected until the creation callback fires; details will be in chrome.runtime.lastError.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                type
item_data_arr.description: The type of menu item. Defaults to normal.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                id
item_data_arr.description: The unique ID to assign to this item. Mandatory for event pages. Cannot be the same as another ID for this extension.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                title
item_data_arr.description: The text to display in the item; this is required unless type is separator. When the context is selection, use %s within the string to show the selected text. For example, if this parameter's value is "Translate '%s' to Pig Latin" and the user selects the word "cool", the context menu item for the selection is "Translate 'cool' to Pig Latin".

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                checked
item_data_arr.description: The initial state of a checkbox or radio button: true for selected, false for unselected. Only one radio button can be selected at a time in a given group.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                contexts
item_data_arr.description: List of contexts this menu item will appear in. Defaults to ['page'].

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                visible
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 62.

Whether the item is visible in the menu.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                onclick
item_data_arr.description: A function that is called back when the menu item is clicked. Event pages cannot use this; instead, they should register a listener for contextMenus.onClicked.

item_data_arr.name: info
item_data_arr.description: Information about the item clicked and the context where the click happened.

item_data_arr.name: menuItemId
item_data_arr.description: The ID of the menu item that was clicked.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                            parentMenuItemId
item_data_arr.description: The parent ID, if any, for the item clicked.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                            mediaType
item_data_arr.description: One of 'image', 'video', or 'audio' if the context menu was activated on one of these types of elements.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                            linkUrl
item_data_arr.description: If the element is a link, the URL it points to.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                            srcUrl
item_data_arr.description: Will be present for elements with a 'src' URL.

item_data_arr.name:

name: cookies
description: Use the chrome.cookies API to query and modify cookies, and to be notified when they change.

item_data_arr.name: get
item_data_arr.description: Retrieves information about a single cookie. If more than one cookie of the same name exists for the given URL, the one with the longest path will be returned. For cookies with the same path length, the cookie with the earliest creation time will be returned.

item_data_arr.name: details
item_data_arr.description: Details to identify the cookie being retrieved.

item_data_arr.name: url
item_data_arr.description: The URL with which the cookie to retrieve is associated. This argument may be a full URL, in which case any data following the URL path (e.g. the query string) is simply ignored. If host permissions for this URL are not specified in the manifest file, the API call will fail.

item_data_arr.name: name
item_data_arr.description: The name of the cookie to retrieve.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                storeId
item_data_arr.description: The ID of the cookie store in which to look for the cookie. By default, the current execution context's cookie store will be used.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function( Cookie cookie) {...};

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                  cookie
item_data_arr.description: Contains details about the cookie. This parameter is null if no such cookie was found.

item_data_arr.name: getAll
item_data_arr.description: Retrieves all cookies from a single cookie store that match the given information. The cookies returned will be sorted, with those with the longest path first. If multiple cookies have the same path length, those with the earliest creation time will be first.

item_data_arr.name: details
item_data_arr.description: Information to filter the cookies being retrieved.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                url
item_data_arr.description: Restricts the retrieved cookies to those that would match the given URL.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                name
item_data_arr.description: Filters the cookies by name.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                domain
item_data_arr.description: Restricts the retrieved cookies to those whose domains match or are subdomains of this one.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                path
item_data_arr.description: Restricts the retrieved cookies to those whose path exactly matches this string.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                secure
item_data_arr.description: Filters the cookies by their Secure property.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                session
item_data_arr.description: Filters out session vs. persistent cookies.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                storeId
item_data_arr.description: The cookie store to retrieve cookies from. If omitted, the current execution context's cookie store will be used.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(array of Cookie cookies) {...};

item_data_arr.name: cookies
item_data_arr.description: All the existing, unexpired cookies that match the given cookie info.

item_data_arr.name: set
item_data_arr.description: Sets a cookie with the given cookie data; may overwrite equivalent cookies if they exist.

item_data_arr.name: details
item_data_arr.description: Details about the cookie being set.

item_data_arr.name: url
item_data_arr.description: The request-URI to associate with the setting of the cookie. This value can affect the default domain and path values of the created cookie. If host permissions for this URL are not specified in the manifest file, the API call will fail.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                name
item_data_arr.description: The name of the cookie. Empty by default if omitted.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                value
item_data_arr.description: The value of the cookie. Empty by default if omitted.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                domain
item_data_arr.description: The domain of the cookie. If omitted, the cookie becomes a host-only cookie.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                path
item_data_arr.description: The path of the cookie. Defaults to the path portion of the url parameter.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                secure
item_data_arr.description: Whether the cookie should be marked as Secure. Defaults to false.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                httpOnly
item_data_arr.description: Whether the cookie should be marked as HttpOnly. Defaults to false.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                sameSite
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 51.

The cookie's same-site status. Defaults to "unspecified", i.e., if omitted, the cookie is set without specifying a SameSite attribute.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                expirationDate
item_data_arr.description: The expiration date of the cookie as the number of seconds since the UNIX epoch. If omitted, the cookie becomes a session cookie.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                storeId
item_data_arr.description: The ID of the cookie store in which to set the cookie. By default, the cookie is set in the current execution context's cookie store.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function( Cookie cookie) {...};

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                  cookie
item_data_arr.description: Contains details about the cookie that's been set. If setting failed for any reason, this will be "null", and "chrome.runtime.lastError" will be set.

item_data_arr.name: remove
item_data_arr.description: Deletes a cookie by name.

item_data_arr.name: details
item_data_arr.description: Information to identify the cookie to remove.

item_data_arr.name: url
item_data_arr.description: The URL associated with the cookie. If host permissions for this URL are not specified in the manifest file, the API call will fail.

item_data_arr.name: name
item_data_arr.description: The name of the cookie to remove.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                storeId
item_data_arr.description: The ID of the cookie store to look in for the cookie. If unspecified, the cookie is looked for by default in the current execution context's cookie store.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function(object details) {...};

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                  details
item_data_arr.description: Contains details about the cookie that's been removed. If removal failed for any reason, this will be "null", and "chrome.runtime.lastError" will be set.

item_data_arr.name: url
item_data_arr.description: The URL associated with the cookie that's been removed.

item_data_arr.description: The ID of the cookie store from which the cookie was removed.

name: debugger
description: The chrome.debugger API serves as an alternate transport for Chrome's remote debugging protocol. Use chrome.debugger to attach to one or more tabs to instrument network interaction, debug JavaScript, mutate the DOM and CSS, etc. Use the Debuggee tabId to target tabs with sendCommand and route events by tabId from onEvent callbacks.

item_data_arr.name: attach
item_data_arr.description: Attaches debugger to the given target.

item_data_arr.name: target
item_data_arr.description: Debugging target to which you want to attach.

item_data_arr.name: requiredVersion
item_data_arr.description: Required debugging protocol version ("0.1"). One can only attach to the debuggee with matching major version and greater or equal minor version. List of the protocol versions can be obtained here.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called once the attach operation succeeds or fails. Callback receives no arguments. If the attach fails, runtime.lastError will be set to the error message.

If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: detach
item_data_arr.description: Detaches debugger from the given target.

item_data_arr.name: target
item_data_arr.description: Debugging target from which you want to detach.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called once the detach operation succeeds or fails. Callback receives no arguments. If the detach fails, runtime.lastError will be set to the error message.

If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: sendCommand
item_data_arr.description: Sends given command to the debugging target.

item_data_arr.name: target
item_data_arr.description: Debugging target to which you want to send the command.

item_data_arr.name: method
item_data_arr.description: Method name. Should be one of the methods defined by the remote debugging protocol.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          commandParams
item_data_arr.description: JSON object with request parameters. This object must conform to the remote debugging params scheme for given method.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
Response body. If an error occurs while posting the message, the callback will be called with no arguments and runtime.lastError will be set to the error message.

If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function(object result) {...};

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                  result
item_data_arr.description: JSON object with the response. Structure of the response varies depending on the method name and is defined by the 'returns' attribute of the command description in the remote debugging protocol.

item_data_arr.name: getTargets
item_data_arr.description: Returns the list of available debug targets.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(array of TargetInfo result) {...};

item_data_arr.name: result
item_data_arr.description: Array of TargetInfo objects corresponding to the available debug targets.

name: declarativeContent
description: Use the chrome.declarativeContent API to take actions depending on the content of a page, without requiring permission to read the page's content.

name: desktopCapture
description: Desktop Capture API that can be used to capture content of screen, individual windows or tabs.

item_data_arr.name: chooseDesktopMedia
item_data_arr.description: Shows desktop media picker UI with the specified set of sources.

item_data_arr.name: sources
item_data_arr.description: Set of sources that should be shown to the user. The sources order in the set decides the tab order in the picker.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          targetTab
item_data_arr.description: Optional tab for which the stream is created. If not specified then the resulting stream can be used only by the calling extension. The stream can only be used by frames in the given tab whose security origin matches tab.url. The tab's origin must be a secure origin, e.g. HTTPS.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(string streamId, object options) {...};

item_data_arr.name: streamId
item_data_arr.description: An opaque string that can be passed to getUserMedia() API to generate media stream that corresponds to the source selected by the user. If user didn't select any source (i.e. canceled the prompt) then the callback is called with an empty streamId. The created streamId can be used only once and expires after a few seconds when it is not used.

item_data_arr.name: options
item_data_arr.description: Contains properties that describe the stream.

item_data_arr.name: canRequestAudioTrack
item_data_arr.description: True if "audio" is included in parameter sources, and the end user does not uncheck the "Share audio" checkbox. Otherwise false, and in this case, one should not ask for audio stream through getUserMedia call.

item_data_arr.name: cancelChooseDesktopMedia
item_data_arr.description: Hides desktop media picker dialog shown by chooseDesktopMedia().

item_data_arr.name: desktopMediaRequestId
item_data_arr.description: Id returned by chooseDesktopMedia()

name: devtools.inspectedWindow
description: Use the chrome.devtools.inspectedWindow API to interact with the inspected window: obtain the tab ID for the inspected page, evaluate the code in the context of the inspected window, reload the page, or obtain the list of resources within the page.

item_data_arr.name: eval
item_data_arr.description: Evaluates a JavaScript expression in the context of the main frame of the inspected page. The expression must evaluate to a JSON-compliant object, otherwise an exception is thrown. The eval function can report either a DevTools-side error or a JavaScript exception that occurs during evaluation. In either case, the result parameter of the callback is undefined. In the case of a DevTools-side error, the isException parameter is non-null and has isError set to true and code set to an error code. In the case of a JavaScript error, isException is set to true and value is set to the string value of thrown object.

item_data_arr.name: expression
item_data_arr.description: An expression to evaluate.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          options
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 38.

The options parameter can contain one or more options.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                frameURL
item_data_arr.description: If specified, the expression is evaluated on the iframe whose URL matches the one specified. By default, the expression is evaluated in the top frame of the inspected page.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                useContentScriptContext
item_data_arr.description: Evaluate the expression in the context of the content script of the calling extension, provided that the content script is already injected into the inspected page. If not, the expression is not evaluated and the callback is invoked with the exception parameter set to an object that has the isError field set to true and the code field set to E_NOTFOUND.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                contextSecurityOrigin
item_data_arr.description: Evaluate the expression in the context of a content script of an extension that matches the specified origin. If given, contextSecurityOrigin overrides the 'true' setting on userContentScriptContext.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
A function called when evaluation completes.

If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function(object result, object exceptionInfo) {...};

item_data_arr.name: result
item_data_arr.description: The result of evaluation.

item_data_arr.name: exceptionInfo
item_data_arr.description: An object providing details if an exception occurred while evaluating the expression.

item_data_arr.name: isError
item_data_arr.description: Set if the error occurred on the DevTools side before the expression is evaluated.

item_data_arr.name: code
item_data_arr.description: Set if the error occurred on the DevTools side before the expression is evaluated.

item_data_arr.name: description
item_data_arr.description: Set if the error occurred on the DevTools side before the expression is evaluated.

item_data_arr.name: details
item_data_arr.description: Set if the error occurred on the DevTools side before the expression is evaluated, contains the array of the values that may be substituted into the description string to provide more information about the cause of the error.

item_data_arr.name: isException
item_data_arr.description: Set if the evaluated code produces an unhandled exception.

item_data_arr.name: value
item_data_arr.description: Set if the evaluated code produces an unhandled exception.

item_data_arr.name: reload
item_data_arr.description: Reloads the inspected page.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                ignoreCache
item_data_arr.description: When true, the loader will bypass the cache for all inspected page resources loaded before the load event is fired. The effect is similar to pressing Ctrl+Shift+R in the inspected window or within the Developer Tools window.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                userAgent
item_data_arr.description: If specified, the string will override the value of the User-Agent HTTP header that's sent while loading the resources of the inspected page. The string will also override the value of the navigator.userAgent property that's returned to any scripts that are running within the inspected page.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                injectedScript
item_data_arr.description: If specified, the script will be injected into every frame of the inspected page immediately upon load, before any of the frame's scripts. The script will not be injected after subsequent reloads—for example, if the user presses Ctrl+R.

item_data_arr.name: getResources
item_data_arr.description: Retrieves the list of resources from the inspected page.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
A function that receives the list of resources when the request completes.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(array of Resource resources) {...};

item_data_arr.name: resources
item_data_arr.description: The resources within the page.

name: downloads
description: Use the chrome.downloads API to programmatically initiate, monitor, manipulate, and search for downloads.

item_data_arr.name: download
item_data_arr.description: Download a URL. If the URL uses the HTTP[S] protocol, then the request will include all cookies currently set for its hostname. If both filename and saveAs are specified, then the Save As dialog will be displayed, pre-populated with the specified filename. If the download started successfully, callback will be called with the new DownloadItem's downloadId. If there was an error starting the download, then callback will be called with downloadId=undefined and runtime.lastError will contain a descriptive string. The error strings are not guaranteed to remain backwards compatible between releases. Extensions must not parse it.

item_data_arr.name: options
item_data_arr.description: What to download and how.

item_data_arr.name: url
item_data_arr.description: The URL to download.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)

item_data_arr.description: A file path relative to the Downloads directory to contain the downloaded file, possibly containing subdirectories. item_data_arr.name: getFileIcon
item_data_arr.description: Retrieve an icon for the specified download. For new downloads, file icons are available after the onCreated event has been received. The image returned by this function while a download is in progress may be different from the image returned after the download is complete. Icon retrieval is done by querying the underlying operating system or toolkit depending on the platform. The icon that is returned will therefore depend on a number of factors including state of the download, platform, registered file types and visual theme. If a file icon cannot be determined, runtime.lastError will contain an error message.

item_data_arr.name: challengeMachineKey
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 50.

Challenges a hardware-backed Enterprise Machine Key and emits the response as part of a remote attestation protocol. Only useful on Chrome OS and in conjunction with the Verified Access Web API which both issues challenges and verifies responses. A successful verification by the Verified Access Web API is a strong signal of all of the following: * The current device is a legitimate Chrome OS device. * The current device is managed by the domain specified during verification. * The current signed-in user is managed by the domain specified during verification. * The current device state complies with enterprise device policy. For example, a policy may specify that the device must not be in developer mode. * Any device identity emitted by the verification is tightly bound to the hardware of the current device. This function is highly restricted and will fail if the current device is not managed, the current user is not managed, or if this operation has not explicitly been enabled for the caller by enterprise device policy. The Enterprise Machine Key does not reside in the "system" token and is not accessible by any other API.

item_data_arr.name: challenge
item_data_arr.description: A challenge as emitted by the Verified Access Web API.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          registerKey
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 59.

If set, the current Enterprise Machine Key is registered with the "system" token and relinquishes the Enterprise Machine Key role. The key can then be associated with a certificate and used like any other signing key. This key is 2048-bit RSA. Subsequent calls to this function will then generate a new Enterprise Machine Key.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called back with the challenge response.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(ArrayBuffer response) {...};

item_data_arr.name: response
item_data_arr.description: The challenge response.

item_data_arr.name: challengeUserKey
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 50.

Challenges a hardware-backed Enterprise User Key and emits the response as part of a remote attestation protocol. Only useful on Chrome OS and in conjunction with the Verified Access Web API which both issues challenges and verifies responses. A successful verification by the Verified Access Web API is a strong signal of all of the following: * The current device is a legitimate Chrome OS device. * The current device is managed by the domain specified during verification. * The current signed-in user is managed by the domain specified during verification. * The current device state complies with enterprise user policy. For example, a policy may specify that the device must not be in developer mode. * The public key emitted by the verification is tightly bound to the hardware of the current device and to the current signed-in user. This function is highly restricted and will fail if the current device is not managed, the current user is not managed, or if this operation has not explicitly been enabled for the caller by enterprise user policy. The Enterprise User Key does not reside in the "user" token and is not accessible by any other API.

item_data_arr.name: challenge
item_data_arr.description: A challenge as emitted by the Verified Access Web API.

item_data_arr.name: registerKey
item_data_arr.description: If set, the current Enterprise User Key is registered with the "user" token and relinquishes the Enterprise User Key role. The key can then be associated with a certificate and used like any other signing key. This key is 2048-bit RSA. Subsequent calls to this function will then generate a new Enterprise User Key.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called back with the challenge response.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(ArrayBuffer response) {...};

item_data_arr.name: response
item_data_arr.description: The challenge response.

name: extension

item_data_arr.description:
Deprecated since Chrome 35. Please use runtime.sendMessage.

Sends a single request to other listeners within the extension. Similar to runtime.connect, but only sends a single request with an optional response. The extension.onRequest event is fired in each page of the extension.

description: Use the chrome.fileSystemProvider API to create file systems, that can be accessible from the file manager on Chrome OS.

item_data_arr.name: mount
item_data_arr.description:
Mounts a file system with the given fileSystemId and displayName. displayName will be shown in the left panel of the Files app. displayName can contain any characters including '/', but cannot be an empty string. displayName must be descriptive but doesn't have to be unique. The fileSystemId must not be an empty string.

Depending on the type of the file system being mounted, the source option must be set appropriately.

In case of an error, runtime.lastError will be set with a corresponding error code.

Since Chrome 45.

Unmounts a file system with the given fileSystemId. It must be called after onUnmountRequested is invoked. Also, the providing extension can decide to perform unmounting if not requested (eg. in case of lost connection, or a file error).

In case of an error, runtime.lastError will be set with a corresponding error code.

Callback to receive the result of getAll function.

item_data_arr.name: get
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 42.

Returns information about a file system with the passed fileSystemId.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
Callback to receive the result of get function.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

item_data_arr.name: notify
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 45.

Notifies about changes in the watched directory at observedPath in recursive mode. If the file system is mounted with supportsNofityTag, then tag must be provided, and all changes since the last notification always reported, even if the system was shutdown. The last tag can be obtained with getAll.

To use, the file_system_provider.notify manifest option must be set to true.

Value of tag can be any string which is unique per call, so it's possible to identify the last registered notification. Eg. if the providing extension starts after a reboot, and the last registered notification's tag is equal to "123", then it should call notify for all changes which happened since the change tagged as "123". It cannot be an empty string.

Not all providers are able to provide a tag, but if the file system has a changelog, then the tag can be eg. a change number, or a revision number.

Note that if a parent directory is removed, then all descendant entries are also removed, and if they are watched, then the API must be notified about the fact. Also, if a directory is renamed, then all descendant entries are in fact removed, as there is no entry under their original paths anymore.

In case of an error, runtime.lastError will be set will a corresponding error code.

item_data_arr.name: fileSystemId
item_data_arr.description: The identifier of the file system related to this change.

item_data_arr.name: observedPath
item_data_arr.description: The path of the observed entry.

item_data_arr.name: recursive
item_data_arr.description: Mode of the observed entry.

item_data_arr.name: changeType
item_data_arr.description: The type of the change which happened to the observed entry. If it is DELETED, then the observed entry will be automatically removed from the list of observed entries.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                changes
item_data_arr.description: List of changes to entries within the observed directory (including the entry itself)

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                tag
item_data_arr.description: Tag for the notification. Required if the file system was mounted with the supportsNotifyTag option. Note, that this flag is necessary to provide notifications about changes which changed even when the system was shutdown.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
A generic result callback to indicate success or failure.

If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

name: gcm
description: Use chrome.gcm to enable apps and extensions to send and receive messages through the Google Cloud Messaging Service.

item_data_arr.name: register
item_data_arr.description: Registers the application with GCM. The registration ID will be returned by the callback. If register is called again with the same list of senderIds, the same registration ID will be returned.

item_data_arr.name: senderIds
item_data_arr.description: A list of server IDs that are allowed to send messages to the application. It should contain at least one and no more than 100 sender IDs.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
Function called when registration completes. It should check runtime.lastError for error when registrationId is empty.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(string registrationId) {...};

item_data_arr.description: A registration ID assigned to the application by the GCM.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
A function called after the unregistration completes. Unregistration was successful if runtime.lastError is not set.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: send
item_data_arr.description: Sends a message according to its contents.

item_data_arr.name: message
item_data_arr.description: A message to send to the other party via GCM.

item_data_arr.name: destinationId
item_data_arr.description: The ID of the server to send the message to as assigned by Google API Console.

item_data_arr.name: messageId
item_data_arr.description: The ID of the message. It must be unique for each message in scope of the applications. See the Cloud Messaging documentation for advice for picking and handling an ID.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                timeToLive
item_data_arr.description: Time-to-live of the message in seconds. If it is not possible to send the message within that time, an onSendError event will be raised. A time-to-live of 0 indicates that the message should be sent immediately or fail if it's not possible. The maximum and a default value of time-to-live is 86400 seconds (1 day).

item_data_arr.name: data
item_data_arr.description: Message data to send to the server. Case-insensitive goog. and google, as well as case-sensitive collapse_key are disallowed as key prefixes. Sum of all key/value pairs should not exceed gcm.MAX_MESSAGE_SIZE.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
A function called after the message is successfully queued for sending. runtime.lastError should be checked, to ensure a message was sent without problems.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(string messageId) {...};

item_data_arr.name: messageId

name: identity
description: Use the chrome.identity API to get OAuth2 access tokens.

item_data_arr.name: getAccounts
item_data_arr.description:
Dev channel only. Learn more.

Retrieves a list of AccountInfo objects describing the accounts present on the profile.

getAccounts is only supported on dev channel.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(array of AccountInfo accounts) {...};

item_data_arr.name: getAuthToken
item_data_arr.description:
Gets an OAuth2 access token using the client ID and scopes specified in the oauth2 section of manifest.json.

The Identity API caches access tokens in memory, so it's ok to call getAuthToken non-interactively any time a token is required. The token cache automatically handles expiration.

For a good user experience it is important interactive token requests are initiated by UI in your app explaining what the authorization is for. Failing to do this will cause your users to get authorization requests, or Chrome sign in screens if they are not signed in, with with no context. In particular, do not use getAuthToken interactively when your app is first launched.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          details
item_data_arr.description: Token options.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                interactive
item_data_arr.description: Fetching a token may require the user to sign-in to Chrome, or approve the application's requested scopes. If the interactive flag is true, getAuthToken will prompt the user as necessary. When the flag is false or omitted, getAuthToken will return failure any time a prompt would be required.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                account
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 37.

The account ID whose token should be returned. If not specified, the function will use an account from the Chrome profile: the Sync account if there is one, or otherwise the first Google web account.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                scopes
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 37.

A list of OAuth2 scopes to request.

When the scopes field is present, it overrides the list of scopes specified in manifest.json.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called with an OAuth2 access token as specified by the manifest, or undefined if there was an error.

If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function(string token) {...};

item_data_arr.name: getProfileUserInfo
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 37.

Retrieves email address and obfuscated gaia id of the user signed into a profile.

This API is different from identity.getAccounts in two ways. The information returned is available offline, and it only applies to the primary account for the profile.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(object userInfo) {...};

item_data_arr.name: email
item_data_arr.description: An email address for the user account signed into the current profile. Empty if the user is not signed in or the identity.email manifest permission is not specified.

item_data_arr.name: id
item_data_arr.description: A unique identifier for the account. This ID will not change for the lifetime of the account. Empty if the user is not signed in or (in M41+) the identity.email manifest permission is not specified.

item_data_arr.name: removeCachedAuthToken
item_data_arr.description:
Removes an OAuth2 access token from the Identity API's token cache.

If an access token is discovered to be invalid, it should be passed to removeCachedAuthToken to remove it from the cache. The app may then retrieve a fresh token with getAuthToken.

item_data_arr.name: details
item_data_arr.description: Token information.

item_data_arr.name: token
item_data_arr.description: The specific token that should be removed from the cache.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called when the token has been removed from the cache.

If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: launchWebAuthFlow
item_data_arr.description:
Starts an auth flow at the specified URL.

This method enables auth flows with non-Google identity providers by launching a web view and navigating it to the first URL in the provider's auth flow. When the provider redirects to a URL matching the pattern https://<app-id>.chromiumapp.org/*, the window will close, and the final redirect URL will be passed to the callback function.

For a good user experience it is important interactive auth flows are initiated by UI in your app explaining what the authorization is for. Failing to do this will cause your users to get authorization requests with no context. In particular, do not launch an interactive auth flow when your app is first launched.

item_data_arr.name: details
item_data_arr.description: WebAuth flow options.

item_data_arr.name: url
item_data_arr.description: The URL that initiates the auth flow.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                interactive
item_data_arr.description:
Whether to launch auth flow in interactive mode.

Since some auth flows may immediately redirect to a result URL, launchWebAuthFlow hides its web view until the first navigation either redirects to the final URL, or finishes loading a page meant to be displayed.

If the interactive flag is true, the window will be displayed when a page load completes. If the flag is false or omitted, launchWebAuthFlow will return with an error if the initial navigation does not complete the flow.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called with the URL redirected back to your application.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(string responseUrl) {...};

item_data_arr.name: getRedirectURL
item_data_arr.description:
Generates a redirect URL to be used in |launchWebAuthFlow|.

The generated URLs match the pattern https://<app-id>.chromiumapp.org/*.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          path
item_data_arr.description: The path appended to the end of the generated URL.

item_data_arr.description: The id of the notification to be updated. This is returned by notifications.create method.

item_data_arr.name: options

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called to indicate whether a matching notification existed.

The callback is required before Chrome 42.

If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function(boolean wasUpdated) {...};

item_data_arr.name: clear
item_data_arr.description: Clears the specified notification.

item_data_arr.name: notificationId
item_data_arr.description: The id of the notification to be cleared. This is returned by notifications.create method.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called to indicate whether a matching notification existed.

The callback is required before Chrome 42.

If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function(boolean wasCleared) {...};

item_data_arr.name: getAll
item_data_arr.description: Retrieves all the notifications of this app or extension.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
Returns the set of notification_ids currently in the system.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(object notifications) {...};

item_data_arr.name: getPermissionLevel
item_data_arr.description: Retrieves whether the user has enabled notifications from this app or extension.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
Returns the current permission level.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function( PermissionLevel level) {...};

name: omnibox
description: The omnibox API allows you to register a keyword with Google Chrome's address bar, which is also known as the omnibox.

item_data_arr.name: setDefaultSuggestion
item_data_arr.description: Sets the description and styling for the default suggestion. The default suggestion is the text that is displayed in the first suggestion row underneath the URL bar.

item_data_arr.name: suggestion
item_data_arr.description: A partial SuggestResult object, without the 'content' parameter.

item_data_arr.name: description
item_data_arr.description: The text that is displayed in the URL dropdown. Can contain XML-style markup for styling. The supported tags are 'url' (for a literal URL), 'match' (for highlighting text that matched what the user's query), and 'dim' (for dim helper text). The styles can be nested, eg. dimmed match.

name: pageAction
description: Use the chrome.pageAction API to put icons in the main Google Chrome toolbar, to the right of the address bar. Page actions represent actions that can be taken on the current page, but that aren't applicable to all pages. Page actions appear grayed out when inactive.

item_data_arr.name: show
item_data_arr.description: Shows the page action. The page action is shown whenever the tab is selected.

item_data_arr.name: tabId
item_data_arr.description: The id of the tab for which you want to modify the page action.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: hide
item_data_arr.description: Hides the page action. Hidden page actions still appear in the Chrome toolbar, but are grayed out.

item_data_arr.name: tabId
item_data_arr.description: The id of the tab for which you want to modify the page action.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: setTitle
item_data_arr.description: Sets the title of the page action. This is displayed in a tooltip over the page action.

item_data_arr.name: tabId
item_data_arr.description: The id of the tab for which you want to modify the page action.

item_data_arr.name: title
item_data_arr.description: The tooltip string.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: getTitle
item_data_arr.description: Gets the title of the page action.

item_data_arr.name: tabId
item_data_arr.description: Specify the tab to get the title from.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(string result) {...};

item_data_arr.name: setIcon
item_data_arr.description: Sets the icon for the page action. The icon can be specified either as the path to an image file or as the pixel data from a canvas element, or as dictionary of either one of those. Either the path or the imageData property must be specified.

item_data_arr.name: tabId
item_data_arr.description: The id of the tab for which you want to modify the page action.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                imageData
item_data_arr.description: Either an ImageData object or a dictionary {size -> ImageData} representing icon to be set. If the icon is specified as a dictionary, the actual image to be used is chosen depending on screen's pixel density. If the number of image pixels that fit into one screen space unit equals scale, then image with size scale * n will be selected, where n is the size of the icon in the UI. At least one image must be specified. Note that 'details.imageData = foo' is equivalent to 'details.imageData = {'16': foo}'

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                path
item_data_arr.description: Either a relative image path or a dictionary {size -> relative image path} pointing to icon to be set. If the icon is specified as a dictionary, the actual image to be used is chosen depending on screen's pixel density. If the number of image pixels that fit into one screen space unit equals scale, then image with size scale * n will be selected, where n is the size of the icon in the UI. At least one image must be specified. Note that 'details.path = foo' is equivalent to 'details.path = {'16': foo}'

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                iconIndex
item_data_arr.description: Deprecated. This argument is ignored.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: setPopup
item_data_arr.description: Sets the html document to be opened as a popup when the user clicks on the page action's icon.

item_data_arr.name: tabId
item_data_arr.description: The id of the tab for which you want to modify the page action.

item_data_arr.name: popup
item_data_arr.description: The html file to show in a popup. If set to the empty string (''), no popup is shown.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: getPopup
item_data_arr.description: Gets the html document set as the popup for this page action.

item_data_arr.name: tabId
item_data_arr.description: Specify the tab to get the popup from.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(string result) {...};

name: pageCapture
description: Use the chrome.pageCapture API to save a tab as MHTML.

item_data_arr.name: saveAsMHTML
item_data_arr.description: Saves the content of the tab with given id as MHTML.

item_data_arr.name: tabId

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called when the MHTML has been generated.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(binary mhtmlData) {...};

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
