item_data_arr.description: The MHTML data as a Blob.

name: permissions
description: Use the chrome.permissions API to request declared optional permissions at run time rather than install time, so users understand why the permissions are needed and grant only those that are necessary.

item_data_arr.name: getAll
item_data_arr.description: Gets the extension's current set of permissions.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function( Permissions permissions) {...};

item_data_arr.name: permissions
item_data_arr.description: The extension's active permissions. Note that the origins property will contain granted origins from those specified in the permissions and optional_permissions keys in the manifest and those associated with Content Scripts.

item_data_arr.name: contains
item_data_arr.description: Checks if the extension has the specified permissions.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(boolean result) {...};

item_data_arr.name: result
item_data_arr.description: True if the extension has the specified permissions. If an origin is specified as both an optional permission and a content script match pattern, this will return false unless both permissions are granted.

item_data_arr.name: request
item_data_arr.description: Requests access to the specified permissions, displaying a prompt to the user if necessary. These permissions must either be defined in the optional_permissions field of the manifest or be required permissions that were withheld by the user. Paths on origin patterns will be ignored. You can request subsets of optional origin permissions; for example, if you specify *://*/* in the optional_permissions section of the manifest, you can request http://example.com/. If there are any problems requesting the permissions, runtime.lastError will be set.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function(boolean granted) {...};

item_data_arr.name: granted
item_data_arr.description: True if the user granted the specified permissions.

item_data_arr.name: remove
item_data_arr.description: Removes access to the specified permissions. If there are any problems removing the permissions, runtime.lastError will be set.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function(boolean removed) {...};

item_data_arr.name: removed
item_data_arr.description: True if the permissions were removed.

name: platformKeys
description: Use the chrome.platformKeys API to access client certificates managed by the platform. If the user or policy grants the permission, an extension can use such a certficate in its custom authentication protocol. E.g. this allows usage of platform managed certificates in third party VPNs (see chrome.vpnProvider).

item_data_arr.name: selectClientCertificates
item_data_arr.description: This function filters from a list of client certificates the ones that are known to the platform, match request and for which the extension has permission to access the certificate and its private key. If interactive is true, the user is presented a dialog where they can select from matching certificates and grant the extension access to the certificate. The selected/filtered client certificates will be passed to callback.

item_data_arr.name: request
item_data_arr.description: Only certificates that match this request will be returned.

item_data_arr.name: certificateTypes
item_data_arr.description: This field is a list of the types of certificates requested, sorted in order of the server's preference. Only certificates of a type contained in this list will be retrieved. If certificateTypes is the empty list, however, certificates of any type will be returned.

item_data_arr.name: certificateAuthorities
item_data_arr.description: List of distinguished names of certificate authorities allowed by the server. Each entry must be a DER-encoded X.509 DistinguishedName.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                clientCerts
item_data_arr.description: If given, the selectClientCertificates operates on this list. Otherwise, obtains the list of all certificates from the platform's certificate stores that are available to this extensions. Entries that the extension doesn't have permission for or which doesn't match the request, are removed.

item_data_arr.name: interactive
item_data_arr.description: If true, the filtered list is presented to the user to manually select a certificate and thereby granting the extension access to the certificate(s) and key(s). Only the selected certificate(s) will be returned. If is false, the list is reduced to all certificates that the extension has been granted access to (automatically or manually).

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(array of Match matches) {...};

item_data_arr.name: matches
item_data_arr.description: The list of certificates that match the request, that the extension has permission for and, if interactive is true, that were selected by the user.

item_data_arr.name: getKeyPair
item_data_arr.description: Passes the key pair of certificate for usage with platformKeys.subtleCrypto to callback.

item_data_arr.name: certificate
item_data_arr.description: The certificate of a Match returned by selectClientCertificates.

item_data_arr.name: parameters
item_data_arr.description:
Determines signature/hash algorithm parameters additionally to the parameters fixed by the key itself. The same parameters are accepted as by WebCrypto's importKey function, e.g. RsaHashedImportParams for a RSASSA-PKCS1-v1_5 key. For RSASSA-PKCS1-v1_5 keys, additionally the parameters { "hash": { "name": "none" } } are supported. The sign function will then apply PKCS#1 v1.5 padding and but not hash the given data.

Currently, this function only supports the "RSASSA-PKCS1-v1_5" algorithm with one of the hashing algorithms "none", "SHA-1", "SHA-256", "SHA-384", and "SHA-512".

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The public and private CryptoKey of a certificate which can only be used with platformKeys.subtleCrypto.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(object publicKey, object privateKey) {...};

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                  privateKey
item_data_arr.description: Might be null if this extension does not have access to it.

item_data_arr.name: subtleCrypto
item_data_arr.description: An implementation of WebCrypto's SubtleCrypto that allows crypto operations on keys of client certificates that are available to this extension.

item_data_arr.name: verifyTLSServerCertificate
item_data_arr.description: Checks whether details.serverCertificateChain can be trusted for details.hostname according to the trust settings of the platform. Note: The actual behavior of the trust verification is not fully specified and might change in the future. The API implementation verifies certificate expiration, validates the certification path and checks trust by a known CA. The implementation is supposed to respect the EKU serverAuth and to support subject alternative names.

item_data_arr.name: serverCertificateChain
item_data_arr.description: Each chain entry must be the DER encoding of a X.509 certificate, the first entry must be the server certificate and each entry must certify the entry preceding it.

item_data_arr.name: hostname
item_data_arr.description: The hostname of the server to verify the certificate for, e.g. the server that presented the serverCertificateChain.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(object result) {...};

item_data_arr.name: trusted
item_data_arr.description: The result of the trust verification: true if trust for the given verification details could be established and false if trust is rejected for any reason.

item_data_arr.name: debug_errors
item_data_arr.description:
If the trust verification failed, this array contains the errors reported by the underlying network layer. Otherwise, this array is empty.

Note: This list is meant for debugging only and may not contain all relevant errors. The errors returned may change in future revisions of this API, and are not guaranteed to be forwards or backwards compatible.

name: power
description: Use the chrome.power API to override the system's power management features.

item_data_arr.name: requestKeepAwake
item_data_arr.description: Requests that power management be temporarily disabled. |level| describes the degree to which power management should be disabled. If a request previously made by the same app is still active, it will be replaced by the new request.

item_data_arr.name: releaseKeepAwake
item_data_arr.description: Releases a request previously made via requestKeepAwake().

name: printerProvider
description: The chrome.printerProvider API exposes events used by print manager to query printers controlled by extensions, to query their capabilities and to submit print jobs to these printers.

name: printingMetrics
description: Use the chrome.printingMetrics API to fetch data about printing usage.

item_data_arr.name: getPrintJobs
item_data_arr.description: Returns the list of the finished print jobs.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(array of PrintJobInfo jobs) {...};

name: privacy
description: Use the chrome.privacy API to control usage of the features in Chrome that can affect a user's privacy. This API relies on the ChromeSetting prototype of the type API for getting and setting Chrome's configuration.

name: proxy
description: Use the chrome.proxy API to manage Chrome's proxy settings. This API relies on the ChromeSetting prototype of the type API for getting and setting the proxy configuration.

name: runtime
description: Use the chrome.runtime API to retrieve the background page, return details about the manifest, and listen for and respond to events in the app or extension lifecycle. You can also use this API to convert the relative path of URLs to fully-qualified URLs.

item_data_arr.name: getBackgroundPage
item_data_arr.description: Retrieves the JavaScript 'window' object for the background page running inside the current extension/app. If the background page is an event page, the system will ensure it is loaded before calling the callback. If there is no background page, an error is set.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(Window backgroundPage) {...};

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                  backgroundPage
item_data_arr.description: The JavaScript 'window' object for the background page.

item_data_arr.name: openOptionsPage
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 42.

Open your Extension's options page, if possible.

The precise behavior may depend on your manifest's options_ui or options_page key, or what Chrome happens to support at the time. For example, the page may be opened in a new tab, within chrome://extensions, within an App, or it may just focus an open options page. It will never cause the caller page to reload.

If your Extension does not declare an options page, or Chrome failed to create one for some other reason, the callback will set lastError.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: getManifest
item_data_arr.description: Returns details about the app or extension from the manifest. The object returned is a serialization of the full manifest file.

item_data_arr.name: getURL
item_data_arr.description: Converts a relative path within an app/extension install directory to a fully-qualified URL.

item_data_arr.name: path
item_data_arr.description: A path to a resource within an app/extension expressed relative to its install directory.

item_data_arr.name: setUninstallURL
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 41.

Sets the URL to be visited upon uninstallation. This may be used to clean up server-side data, do analytics, and implement surveys. Maximum 255 characters.

item_data_arr.name: url
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 35.

URL to be opened after the extension is uninstalled. This URL must have an http: or https: scheme. Set an empty string to not open a new tab upon uninstallation.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called when the uninstall URL is set. If the given URL is invalid, runtime.lastError will be set.

If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: reload
item_data_arr.description: Reloads the app or extension. This method is not supported in kiosk mode. For kiosk mode, use chrome.runtime.restart() method.

item_data_arr.name: requestUpdateCheck
item_data_arr.description:
Requests an immediate update check be done for this app/extension.

Important: Most extensions/apps should not use this method, since chrome already does automatic checks every few hours, and you can listen for the runtime.onUpdateAvailable event without needing to call requestUpdateCheck.

This method is only appropriate to call in very limited circumstances, such as if your extension/app talks to a backend service, and the backend service has determined that the client extension/app version is very far out of date and you'd like to prompt a user to update. Most other uses of requestUpdateCheck, such as calling it unconditionally based on a repeating timer, probably only serve to waste client, network, and server resources.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function( RequestUpdateCheckStatus status, object details) {...};

item_data_arr.name: status
item_data_arr.description: Result of the update check.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                  details
item_data_arr.description: If an update is available, this contains more information about the available update.

item_data_arr.name: version
item_data_arr.description: The version of the available update.

item_data_arr.name: restart
item_data_arr.description: Restart the ChromeOS device when the app runs in kiosk mode. Otherwise, it's no-op.

item_data_arr.name: restartAfterDelay
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 53.

Restart the ChromeOS device when the app runs in kiosk mode after the given seconds. If called again before the time ends, the reboot will be delayed. If called with a value of -1, the reboot will be cancelled. It's a no-op in non-kiosk mode. It's only allowed to be called repeatedly by the first extension to invoke this API.

item_data_arr.name: seconds
item_data_arr.description: Time to wait in seconds before rebooting the device, or -1 to cancel a scheduled reboot.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
A callback to be invoked when a restart request was successfully rescheduled.

If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: connect
item_data_arr.description: Attempts to connect to connect listeners within an extension/app (such as the background page), or other extensions/apps. This is useful for content scripts connecting to their extension processes, inter-app/extension communication, and web messaging. Note that this does not connect to any listeners in a content script. Extensions may connect to content scripts embedded in tabs via tabs.connect.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          extensionId
item_data_arr.description: The ID of the extension or app to connect to. If omitted, a connection will be attempted with your own extension. Required if sending messages from a web page for web messaging.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                name
item_data_arr.description: Will be passed into onConnect for processes that are listening for the connection event.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                includeTlsChannelId
item_data_arr.description: Whether the TLS channel ID will be passed into onConnectExternal for processes that are listening for the connection event.

item_data_arr.name: connectNative
item_data_arr.description: Connects to a native application in the host machine. See Native Messaging for more information.

item_data_arr.name: application
item_data_arr.description: The name of the registered application to connect to.

item_data_arr.name: sendMessage
item_data_arr.description: Sends a single message to event listeners within your extension/app or a different extension/app. Similar to runtime.connect but only sends a single message, with an optional response. If sending to your extension, the runtime.onMessage event will be fired in every frame of your extension (except for the sender's frame), or runtime.onMessageExternal, if a different extension. Note that extensions cannot send messages to content scripts using this method. To send messages to content scripts, use tabs.sendMessage.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          extensionId
item_data_arr.description: The ID of the extension/app to send the message to. If omitted, the message will be sent to your own extension/app. Required if sending messages from a web page for web messaging.

item_data_arr.name: message
item_data_arr.description: The message to send. This message should be a JSON-ifiable object.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                includeTlsChannelId
item_data_arr.description: Whether the TLS channel ID will be passed into onMessageExternal for processes that are listening for the connection event.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          responseCallback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the responseCallback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function(any response) {...};

item_data_arr.name: response
item_data_arr.description: The JSON response object sent by the handler of the message. If an error occurs while connecting to the extension, the callback will be called with no arguments and runtime.lastError will be set to the error message.

item_data_arr.name: sendNativeMessage
item_data_arr.description: Send a single message to a native application.

item_data_arr.name: application
item_data_arr.description: The name of the native messaging host.

item_data_arr.name: message
item_data_arr.description: The message that will be passed to the native messaging host.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          responseCallback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the responseCallback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function(any response) {...};

item_data_arr.name: response
item_data_arr.description: The response message sent by the native messaging host. If an error occurs while connecting to the native messaging host, the callback will be called with no arguments and runtime.lastError will be set to the error message.

item_data_arr.name: getPlatformInfo
item_data_arr.description: Returns information about the current platform.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called with results

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function( PlatformInfo platformInfo) {...};

item_data_arr.name: getPackageDirectoryEntry
item_data_arr.description: Returns a DirectoryEntry for the package directory.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(DirectoryEntry directoryEntry) {...};

name: sessions
description: Use the chrome.sessions API to query and restore tabs and windows from a browsing session.

item_data_arr.name: getRecentlyClosed
item_data_arr.description: Gets the list of recently closed tabs and/or windows.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(array of Session sessions) {...};

item_data_arr.name: sessions
item_data_arr.description: The list of closed entries in reverse order that they were closed (the most recently closed tab or window will be at index 0). The entries may contain either tabs or windows.

item_data_arr.name: getDevices
item_data_arr.description: Retrieves all devices with synced sessions.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(array of Device devices) {...};

item_data_arr.name: devices
item_data_arr.description: The list of sessions.Device objects for each synced session, sorted in order from device with most recently modified session to device with least recently modified session. tabs.Tab objects are sorted by recency in the windows.Window of the sessions.Session objects.

item_data_arr.name: restore
item_data_arr.description: Reopens a windows.Window or tabs.Tab, with an optional callback to run when the entry has been restored.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          sessionId
item_data_arr.description: The windows.Window.sessionId, or tabs.Tab.sessionId to restore. If this parameter is not specified, the most recently closed session is restored.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function( Session restoredSession) {...};

item_data_arr.name: restoredSession
item_data_arr.description: A sessions.Session containing the restored windows.Window or tabs.Tab object.

name: storage
description: Use the chrome.storage API to store, retrieve, and track changes to user data.

name: system.cpu
description: Use the system.cpu API to query CPU metadata.

item_data_arr.name: getInfo
item_data_arr.description: Queries basic CPU information of the system.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(object info) {...};

item_data_arr.name: numOfProcessors
item_data_arr.description: The number of logical processors.

item_data_arr.name: archName
item_data_arr.description: The architecture name of the processors.

item_data_arr.name: modelName

name: tabCapture
description: Use the chrome.tabCapture API to interact with tab media streams.

item_data_arr.name: capture
item_data_arr.description: Captures the visible area of the currently active tab. Capture can only be started on the currently active tab after the extension has been invoked, similar to the way that activeTab works. Capture is maintained across page navigations within the tab, and stops when the tab is closed, or the media stream is closed by the extension.

item_data_arr.name: options
item_data_arr.description: Configures the returned media stream.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
Callback with either the tab capture MediaStream or null. null indicates an error has occurred and the client may query chrome.runtime.lastError to access the error details.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(LocalMediaStream stream) {...};

item_data_arr.name: getCapturedTabs
item_data_arr.description: Returns a list of tabs that have requested capture or are being captured, i.e. status != stopped and status != error. This allows extensions to inform the user that there is an existing tab capture that would prevent a new tab capture from succeeding (or to prevent redundant requests for the same tab).

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
Callback invoked with CaptureInfo[] for captured tabs.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(array of CaptureInfo result) {...};

item_data_arr.name: captureOffscreenTab
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 47.

Creates an off-screen tab and navigates it to the given |startUrl|. Then, capture is started and a MediaStream is returned via |callback|.

Off-screen tabs are isolated from the user's normal browser experience. They do not show up in the browser window or tab strip, nor are they visible to extensions (e.g., via the chrome.tabs.* APIs).

An off-screen tab remains alive until one of three events occurs: 1. All MediaStreams providing its captured content are closed; 2. the page self-closes (e.g., via window.close()); 3. the extension that called captureOffscreenTab() is unloaded.

Sandboxing: The off-screen tab does not have any access whatsoever to the local user profile (including cookies, HTTP auth, etc.). Instead, it is provided its own sandboxed profile. Also, it cannot access any interactive resources such as keyboard/mouse input, media recording devices (e.g., web cams), copy/paste to/from the system clipboard, etc.

Note: This is a new API, currently only available in Canary/Dev channel, and may change without notice.

item_data_arr.name: options
item_data_arr.description: Constraints for the capture and returned MediaStream.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
Callback with either the tab capture MediaStream or null. null indicates an error has occurred and the client may query chrome.runtime.lastError to access the error details.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(LocalMediaStream stream) {...};

item_data_arr.name: getMediaStreamId
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 71.

Creates a stream ID to capture the target tab. Similar to chrome.tabCapture.capture() method, but returns a media stream ID, instead of a media stream, to the consumer tab.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                consumerTabId
item_data_arr.description: Optional tab id of the tab which will later invoke getUserMedia() to consume the stream. If not specified then the resulting stream can be used only by the calling extension. The stream can only be used by frames in the given tab whose security origin matches the consumber tab's origin. The tab's origin must be a secure origin, e.g. HTTPS.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                targetTabId
item_data_arr.description: Optional tab id of the tab which will be captured. If not specified then the current active tab will be selected. Only tabs for which the extension has been granted the activeTab permission can be used as the target tab.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
Callback to invoke with the result. If successful, the result is an opaque string that can be passed to the getUserMedia() API to generate a media stream that corresponds to the target tab. The created streamId can only be used once and expires after a few seconds if it is not used.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(string streamId) {...};

item_data_arr.name: zoomFactor

name: tts
description: Use the chrome.tts API to play synthesized text-to-speech (TTS). See also the related ttsEngine API, which allows an extension to implement a speech engine.

item_data_arr.name: speak
item_data_arr.description: Speaks text using a text-to-speech engine.

item_data_arr.name: utterance
item_data_arr.description: The text to speak, either plain text or a complete, well-formed SSML document. Speech engines that do not support SSML will strip away the tags and speak the text. The maximum length of the text is 32,768 characters.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          options
item_data_arr.description: The speech options.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called right away, before speech finishes. Check chrome.runtime.lastError to make sure there were no errors. Use options.onEvent to get more detailed feedback.

If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: stop
item_data_arr.description: Stops any current speech and flushes the queue of any pending utterances. In addition, if speech was paused, it will now be un-paused for the next call to speak.

item_data_arr.name: pause
item_data_arr.description: Pauses speech synthesis, potentially in the middle of an utterance. A call to resume or stop will un-pause speech.

item_data_arr.name: resume
item_data_arr.description: If speech was paused, resumes speaking where it left off.

item_data_arr.name: isSpeaking
item_data_arr.description: Checks whether the engine is currently speaking. On Mac OS X, the result is true whenever the system speech engine is speaking, even if the speech wasn't initiated by Chrome.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function(boolean speaking) {...};

item_data_arr.name: speaking
item_data_arr.description: True if speaking, false otherwise.

item_data_arr.name: getVoices
item_data_arr.description: Gets an array of all available voices.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function(array of TtsVoice voices) {...};

item_data_arr.name: voices
item_data_arr.description: Array of tts.TtsVoice objects representing the available voices for speech synthesis.

name: ttsEngine
description: Use the chrome.ttsEngine API to implement a text-to-speech(TTS) engine using an extension. If your extension registers using this API, it will receive events containing an utterance to be spoken and other parameters when any extension or Chrome App uses the tts API to generate speech. Your extension can then use any available web technology to synthesize and output the speech, and send events back to the calling function to report the status.

item_data_arr.name: updateVoices
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 66.

Called by an engine to update its list of voices. This list overrides any voices declared in this extension's manifest.

item_data_arr.name: voices
item_data_arr.description: Array of tts.TtsVoice objects representing the available voices for speech synthesis.

name: vpnProvider
description: Use the chrome.vpnProvider API to implement a VPN client.

item_data_arr.name: createConfig
item_data_arr.description: Creates a new VPN configuration that persists across multiple login sessions of the user.

item_data_arr.name: name

Called when the configuration is created or if there is an error.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function(string id) {...};

item_data_arr.name: id
item_data_arr.description: A unique ID for the created configuration, or undefined on failure.

item_data_arr.name: destroyConfig
item_data_arr.description: Destroys a VPN configuration created by the extension.

item_data_arr.name: id
item_data_arr.description: ID of the VPN configuration to destroy.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)

item_data_arr.description:
Called when the configuration is destroyed or if there is an error.

If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: setParameters
item_data_arr.description: Sets the parameters for the VPN session. This should be called immediately after "connected" is received from the platform. This will succeed only when the VPN session is owned by the extension.

item_data_arr.name: parameters
item_data_arr.description: The parameters for the VPN session.

item_data_arr.name: address
item_data_arr.description: IP address for the VPN interface in CIDR notation. IPv4 is currently the only supported mode.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                broadcastAddress
item_data_arr.description: Broadcast address for the VPN interface. (default: deduced from IP address and mask)

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                mtu
item_data_arr.description: MTU setting for the VPN interface. (default: 1500 bytes)

item_data_arr.name: exclusionList
item_data_arr.description: Exclude network traffic to the list of IP blocks in CIDR notation from the tunnel. This can be used to bypass traffic to and from the VPN server. When many rules match a destination, the rule with the longest matching prefix wins. Entries that correspond to the same CIDR block are treated as duplicates. Such duplicates in the collated (exclusionList + inclusionList) list are eliminated and the exact duplicate entry that will be eliminated is undefined.

item_data_arr.name: inclusionList
item_data_arr.description: Include network traffic to the list of IP blocks in CIDR notation to the tunnel. This parameter can be used to set up a split tunnel. By default no traffic is directed to the tunnel. Adding the entry "0.0.0.0/0" to this list gets all the user traffic redirected to the tunnel. When many rules match a destination, the rule with the longest matching prefix wins. Entries that correspond to the same CIDR block are treated as duplicates. Such duplicates in the collated (exclusionList + inclusionList) list are eliminated and the exact duplicate entry that will be eliminated is undefined.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                domainSearch
item_data_arr.description: A list of search domains. (default: no search domain)

item_data_arr.name: dnsServers
item_data_arr.description: A list of IPs for the DNS servers.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                                reconnect
item_data_arr.description:
Since Chrome 51.

Whether or not the VPN extension implements auto-reconnection.

If true, the linkDown, linkUp, linkChanged, suspend, and resume platform messages will be used to signal the respective events. If false, the system will forcibly disconnect the VPN if the network topology changes, and the user will need to reconnect manually. (default: false)

This property is new in Chrome 51; it will generate an exception in earlier versions. try/catch can be used to conditionally enable the feature based on browser support.

item_data_arr.name: callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called when the parameters are set or if there is an error.

The callback parameter should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: sendPacket
item_data_arr.description: Sends an IP packet through the tunnel created for the VPN session. This will succeed only when the VPN session is owned by the extension.

item_data_arr.name: data
item_data_arr.description: The IP packet to be sent to the platform.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called when the packet is sent or if there is an error.

If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: notifyConnectionStateChanged
item_data_arr.description: Notifies the VPN session state to the platform. This will succeed only when the VPN session is owned by the extension.

item_data_arr.name: state
item_data_arr.description: The VPN session state of the VPN client.

item_data_arr.name:
(optional)
                          callback
item_data_arr.description:
Called when the notification is complete or if there is an error.

If you specify the callback parameter, it should be a function that looks like this:

function() {...};

item_data_arr.name: create
item_data_arr.description: Creates (opens) a new browser window with any optional sizing, position, or default URL provided.
